com.googlecode.streamflyer.core

Class Documentation

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.googlecode.streamflyer.core.Documentation

  • public class Documentation
extends Object
    Read this first, before you use Streamflyer. This Javadoc content is also available on the Streamflyer web page.

    Contents

    1. When shall I use this library?
    2. How do I modify character streams?
    3. Which type of modifications are provided out-of-the-box?
    4. What is the benefit of this library in comparison to sed or Perl?
    5. Can I use regular expressions to modify streams?
    6. How much memory does a modifying reader or writer consume?
    7. How big is the performance overhead of a modifying reader or modfying writer?
    8. How do I process regex patterns found in the character stream a more specific way?
    9. Is there a way to modify byte streams instead of character streams, i.e. is there something like a modifying input stream or output stream?

    1. When shall I use this library?

    This library provides filter that modify character streams on-the-fly with a small memory foot-print using the Java interfaces Reader and Writer. Additionally, you can use these filters to report some patterns found in character streams without modifying the content of the character streams.

    Use this library only if you use Java 6 or higher.

    If you want to optimize the speed of the stream modifications and you don't care of memory consumption (assuming you are in the cloud), then load the entire content of the stream into the memory and modify the stream content there. In this case this library is not the right choice for you because this library minimizes the use of memory at the expense of a reduced speed of the stream modifications.

    2. How do I modify character streams?

    First you have to implement a callback that makes the desired modifications on a small part of the entire character stream. The contract of that callback is defined by Modifier. For some common use cases pre-defined modifiers exist.

    Second, wrap the original reader or writer with a modifying reader or writer.

    Example for a modifying reader that removes invalid characters from XML files: 

    // choose the character stream to modify
Reader originalReader = ... // this reader is connected to the original data source

// select the modifier
Modifier myModifier = new InvalidXmlCharacterModifier(1024, "", "1.0", false);

// create the modifying reader that wraps the original reader
Reader modifyingReader = new ModifyingReader(originalReader, myModifier);

... // use the modifying reader instead of the original reader

    3. Which modifiers are provided out-of-the-box?

    The following modifications are provided out-of-the-box.

    • RegexModifier: Replaces characters using regular expressions.
    • XmlVersionModifier: Changes the version in the prolog of XML files.
    • InvalidXmlCharacterModifier: Replaces invalid XML characters in XML files or removes them from XML files.
    • RangeFilterModifier (experimental module): Removes everything from the stream apart from the content between a start tag and an end tag.
    The factories ModifyingReaderFactory and ModifyingWriterFactory ease the use of these modifiers.

    Do you know another common use case that should be supported by this library? Then, please let the author know. A corresponding modifier might be added to the library in a future version.

    4. What is the benefit of this library in comparison to sed or awk or Perl?

    The line-based approach of sed consumes a lot of memory if you modify a large XML file that does contain no or only a few line breaks. The modifications sed can carry out are limited to replacements using regular expressions. This library instead supports any kind of modification and consumes not much memory how big the processed file may be. In comparison to awk and perl, this library seamlessly integrates with Java software that uses the interfaces for character streams (Reader and Writer).

    5. Can I use regular expressions to modify streams?

    Yes. Use the RegexModifier directly or, more convenient, use the ModifyingReaderFactory or the ModifyingWriterFactory.

    6. How much memory does a modifying reader or writer consume?

    This depends entirely on the used Modifier and the task the modifier has to fulfill. Basically the modifier defines the number of characters to process at once by AfterModification.getNewNumberOfChars(). This is the minimum of characters in the memory. The API documentation of each modifier implementation should make clear how much memory the modifier consumes at most. Double that number (the maximum number of characters to be processed at once), then you got the maximum capacity of the used character buffer, i.e. the number of characters in the memory. Hint: The number must be doubled due to the internal implementation of Java's StringBuilder.ensureCapacity(int).

    7. How big is the performance overhead of a modifying reader or modifying writer that does nothing (no modification, no logging etc.) in comparison to the use of a reader or writer that reads its data directly from memory?

    If you use such an idle modifier to process 10 million characters using a buffer of 500 characters, then the overhead is 0.2 seconds using a modifying reader and 0.4 seconds using a modifying writer (normal PC, 2011).

    8. How do I process regex patterns found in the character stream?

    By default RegexModifier will replace the matches with the given replacement. If you want to do more or something else (logging, arbitrary insertions), then implement your own MatchProcessor, and use it with the RegexModifier.

    9. Is there a way to modify byte streams instead of character streams, i.e. is there something like a modifying input stream or output stream?

    No, at the moment there is no special code for byte streams. An approach could be to define your own CharsetDecoder and CharsetEncoder , then convert the byte stream to a pseudo character stream, modify the character stream, and then convert the pseudo characters back to bytes. Is the performance of this approach still sufficient despite the two conversions? Let me know if you tried this.
